column1: Will there be a lethal confrontation between the national military forces, militia, and/or law enforcement personnel the People's Republic of China (PRC) and those of any other country before 28 November 2022?
column6: ['Foreign Policy', 'Security and Conflict']
It's always the same question. I can't follow you
It's hihly imporbable in yhe next 4 hours.
Because you are 4 hours ahead
Because deadline is tomorrow
Bexause it's tomorrow.
Because it's tomorrow.
Five hours left— unlikely to occur spontaneously without existing conditions
Updating because there is only one day left
There has been anti-lockdown protests, but nothing new in terms of external relations
latest condition shows very little chance of such a thing.
Late to the party.
Xi has not proven emotional in deeds
Nothing indicating that it can happen in such a short time
China appears to be emphasizing diplomacy in recent times.
No lethal confrontation will occur between the Peoples Republic of China (PRC) and Taiwan as well as Japan between now and 28 November 2022.
it won’t be reported but it already has on the east side of Hong Kong three US Navy ships were attacked and in the ocean now a Chinese aircraft carrier is sinking 5 …4…3…2….1
No hints of conflict, and highly unlikely given the delicate diplomatic balance China is engaged with with the US.
Short time to close - low probability
Probably not in the next week. I made a mistake in not updating my forecast earlier.
Definitely not now that it's late autumn

There is so little time left. China seems much more focused on updating its governing body after Xi's reelection and its zero-COVID policy to engage in military conflict in the near future. Additionally, China is already reeling economically from COVID. It seems unlikely it would pick a fight with the US right before the Western holiday buying season. Even though it hurts to put a 0%, as my friend would say "ain't no way" China fights another country in the next week.
Time is running out, thankfully.
Going to 0%, there's 10 days left.
Nothing in the news has led me to change my strong expectation that there will not be a lethal confrontation
Biden Xi meeting and other bilateral meetings at G-20 summit further reduces any chance of standoff.
https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2022-11-16/china-won-t-be-able-to-attack-taiwan-in-near-future-milley-says?leadSource=uverify%20wall
I am updating my forecast from 5% to 1% given that this question is closing shortly.

I am reducing my forecast to 1% for two main reasons. One, there are only 12 days left in the forecasting window. Two, the Biden-Xi face-to-face meeting at the G20 indicates that both sides desire a constructive relationship moving forward. If the next 12 days were to occur 100 times, I estimate that in only one of those times would the question yield a result of True.
https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/statements-releases/2022/11/14/readout-of-president-joe-bidens-meeting-with-president-xi-jinping-of-the-peoples-republic-of-china/
Lower probability as the time frame nears an end.
not much time left before then, and think both sides will be cautious. Allowing for 2% probability as an accident may happen.
Updating because the date is closer.
Edging my number down to account for the narrowing window of possibility and lack of catalyst for the PRC to initiate such a conflict.
China's growing disapproval of Russia's attack might indicate that they will not engage, at last in the near future, in such action themselves.

I do not have a reason to change. Crowd forecast is now 96%, while I am at 97%. Russia withdrew from Kherson, perhaps signaling to other potential aggressors that swift and certain outcomes are unlikely while short and long-term costs are significant and more certain.
Hasn't happened yet
Not while Xi is out of the country at different summits and such, which he will be for the remainder of November.
We are close on ending of November, and plus I don’t think China can effort war now , seeing it still recovering from Covid-19 .
Low base rate and time window very short, wish I had seen this question a while back
Holidays
Hasn't happened yet seems unlikely it will now.
Reduced to 1% based on the amount of time left for this question.
Decreasing probability as there are currently no signs or buildup to a lethal confrontation between China and another country and the question closes in 19 days.
For Xi, Taiwan may always be a question of when and not whether to make a move, but there is little incentive for the PRC to act now.
https://www.state.gov/secretary-blinkens-call-with-peoples-republic-of-china-prc-state-councilor-and-foreign-minister-wang-yi-3/
CPC party congress is over, and writ of President Xi firmly established, chances of lethal confrontation is nearly zero.
I'm decreasing my forecast again because I believe that China is focusing on reinvigorating its economy in the short term. This makes an intentional international conflict less likely.
No confrontations have happened yet and the time available continues to dwindle.
With less than a month left - the likelihood of this occurring continues to drop.
Dropping to 1%. 26 days left.
Updating from 6 to 5 since as the date is closer, the probability decreases.
I don't have a reason to change.

No change to my forecast but Xi's third term as CCP Chairman does provide additional political capital and time to take bold action. https://www.wsj.com/articles/taiwan-braces-for-grim-times-after-chinas-xi-extends-power-11666878661

Reduced the probability on 28th October to 3% given that there has been no significant positive or negative development related to a potential confrontation and we are moving closer to the end date of the question.
Less chance of conflict as time goes by.
The United States has said publicly that would intervene in a confrontation between China and Taiwan.
no one has changed their position on this question.
Nothing has come up in the news to make me change my assessment

Starting with 5%. A lethal confrontation is a pretty high bar. In recent history, I think the only ones have been with India. And, India and China seem to have come to an agreement to calm down their border area, for now at least.
With Xi Jin Ping being reelected, he may have less incentive to engage in such lethal confrontation.

After the latest CPC-wide meeting, Xi Jinping is now more powerful than ever--a solidified position for him at the helm of the country's political leadership. https://www.politico.com/news/2022/10/24/xi-weak-spot-economy-00063171
no new data
I have not identified a reason to change my forecast. As tensions rise due to Russian's war on Ukraine, I think the need for global restraint grows.

Lowering the probability slightly as we are getting closer to the closing of this question. While fbiber's rationale is very strong (looked at Xi Jinping's speech at the 20th Party Congress and the President's explicit reference to Taiwan as an objective of Chinese foreign policy, and reassurance that "we will never promise to renounce the use of force and we reserve the option of taking all measures necessary"), given that the question ends end of November, I think the probability of a lethal confrontation is low.
I think there is less likely to be lethal confrontation while the country is focused on the PRC's Congress. Additionally, other countries are preoccupied by the Ukraine/Russia war.
Updating my forecast based on the temporal factor
During the PRC's Congress, there is a less likely chance that an incident would occur that results in a lethal incident.

No new information has arisen to get me to adjust my prediction, but I still think the communist party conference makes this a particularly sensitive time that the CCP will want to navigate without major controversy or violent confonrtation.
Based on the re-election and expected lack of major surprises in terms of war at least till the Russia-Ukraine war hopefully settles down.
Xi Jinping will likely be re-elected as CCP Chair for another 5 years this week. His speech yesterday suggests that he's keen to flex China's muscles on the world stage.
There has been no rise in tensions between India and China lately.

During this week, China held its 20th Party Congress where President Xi Xinping is expected to secure an unpredecented third term (before, Chinese leaders were expected to rule up to two terms or 10 years). In his opening speech, Xi focused on Covid-lockdown measures and diplomacy. He explicitly mentioned Taiwan as an objective of Chinese foreign policy, and was emphatic that "we will never promise to renounce the use of force and we reserve the option of taking all measures necessary". Thus, once Xi is ordained for his third term, one can expect a more assertive role of China in the international sphere.

The Chinese call for de-escalation in the Ukrainian war signals the PRC will to focus on the economy, both on national growth and on exports enhancement, strengthening global supply chains and having access to advanced technology. A confrontation could only exacerbate the polarization and impede Chinese recovery and ext of the zero covid policy.
Lowering my forecast as the forecast horizon has shrunk

China, overtly, presents itself as a stabilizing force (and by implication stabilizing world power) while engaging in destabilizing internationally accepted norms and standards, including its ostensible stabilizing multiplying factors in its restive domestic regions while violating human rights and engaging in genocidal activity. Given all this, it is unlikely to engage militarily where its actions cannot be obscured. With its decision to elevate Xi in short order, it will continue its strategic interactions by authoritarian means domestically with grey zone strategies internationally. In short, this event is highly unlikely.
Holding at 2% to reflect that the risk goes down as the end of the forecast period approaches.
Confirming my prior forecast as there was no major event that would increase the probability of a lethal confrontation

Every passing week where a lethal confrontation does not occur leaves me more confident that one will not by 28 November. Also, the upcoming CCP Party conference suggests they will not be interested in instigating a conflict, as it might cause political troubles at a sensitive time for the leadership
Given the global response to Russia following the invasion of Ukraine as well as the already difficult economic conditions in PRC this seems highly unlikely.

Taiwan and India are the two likely countries with which PRC would have a lethal confrontation. With the Ukraine-Russia war escalating, I don't see other countries going into lethal confrontations which would heighten geopolitical risks. So I am decreasing the probability from 14% to 12%.
Don't expect anything to happen in the lead up to the Party Congress, will continue to monitor to note any trends or key messages delivered that could impact the question.
Adjusting slightly downwards given time that has passed
- China will not make a military move before seeing the outcome of Russia’s attack on Ukraine

Of each of these, it's possible that a confrontation with India would be most likely (numerically), and one with Taiwan (but more likely due to equipment failure of an aircraft, not a deliberate lethal engagement. With India, it's based on historical conflicts in the region, with the most recent one being in 2020. However, the vast majority of the skirmishes have always been without the use of weapons, which lowers the lethality. With Taiwan, President Xi is likely to be overly conservative until after the Congress meets. What would change my prediction is if Xi has inflammatory language about imminently seizing Taiwan, or we see a large military buildup, but I don't see all of that happening in the next 1.5 months.
Updating from 8 to 7 since as the date is closer, the probability decreases.

I found comments by other forecasters on Xi Jinping's focus on stability in domestic politics with the coming National Congress in October compelling and that is why I have decreased the probability to 14%.
If conflict were to occur, the most likely scenario would be between India and China during a border dispute.
SunTsu@ferryman
Taking the case of Taiwan:
Revising downward given relative quiet period of late.

The next few months will be about stability for Xi and the CCP. That is not to say there will be no saber rattling. Quite the contrary. Xi will, through his ministers, continue to assert CCP/his interests through the other instruments of power. However, Xi will seek to avoid any deliberate, major armed confrontation in the East and South China Seas while he cements his consolidation of power domestically and takes advantage of his competitors' concentration elsewhere. He may allow some small-scale confrontation along the Line of Actual Control with India, wagering that his strategic opponents will do little in response.
I don't have a compelling reason to change my probability right now.
Increased marginally based on a new report which suggests that China is building new infrastructure in the border region with India, close to Bhutan.
The theme of James Bond should be playing when I’m forecasting.

If there were to be kinetic conflict, China would most likely attack Taiwan-controlled islands, such as Kinmen or Matsu, in a bid to exercise martial-law level control and rally patriotic sentiment with the people. However, with the Party Congress only a few weeks ago, Xi is unlikely to introduce any complicating factors at this late stage that would risk his election for a 3rd term as President + Chairman for Life.
Meeting of the National Congress in October tends to result in new political order within the CCP. Unlikely to engage in foreign confrontations with gamesmanship between party officials taking place.
Adjustment. Passage of time. It might not be this year. But I belive we will see an invasion in Taiwan in this decade.
Rumor has it, there may be a coup in China. However, there has not been any confirmation.
I had moved it up previously based on the rumors of a coup; however, given reporting that those were false, I have dropped it back down

News of a purported coup in China, Xi under arrest, spread on social media today. Misinformation spreading over claims air traffic in China had stopped, others spreading rumors that thousands of flights had been cancelled the whole thing went viral with many verified accounts falling for it and helping spread it further). There's no indication whatsover from realiable sources of any issues affecting the Chinese government or Xi's hold on power.

The problem with this question is that is is too broad: "Any other country" is an incredibly broad sample size to look at, especially given that "one fatality total", is also a very small target to hit. By virtue of human nature and the current geopolitical tensions the probability won't be 0. At the same time, these tensions also make conflict more costly - which will probably lead to orders of more restraint and greater control in border zones (which are most prone to conflict). The last active Conflict China was involved in at the Sino-Indian border led to lethal fatalities in 2020, so 2 years ago.
This seems highly unlikely that a lethal conflict could arise this quickly between now and November between the PRC and another country, especially given the war in Ukraine,
Highly unlikely unless Russia fires a couple of nukes into Europe

Globally, the absolute number of war deaths has been declining since 1946. There are very few lethal confrontations between national military forces and law enforcement overall. Given Russia's war with Ukraine, China is even less likely to do any lethal confrontation.
India and China are de-escalating.
It is unlikely given the escalating War in Ukraine that China will engage in armed conflict with Taiwan before 28 November 2022.

Last year, "China revealed soldier deaths in India border clash" (BBC). This year, "Top Taiwan official found dead as China accused of attack simulation" (Yahoo News). Deaths are not frequent, but while some conflicts are escalating (given the latest positions by the US on Tawain and the way the war is escalating in Russia), I believe China will do everything in its power to avoid jumping into the news to casualties.

In view of the unlikelihood of any major military adventurism in the run up to or just after the CPC congress and recent China India disengagement before the SCO summit, I would assign just 4% probability for a lethal confrontation between PRC and any other country.

Super low base rate, would go even lower if not for the history of near misses (see a similar question in the original IARPA run), but equally I don't think a well-structured rationale by someone higher couldn't push me up to 3-4%.
As it's about a lethal confrontation, which might take time to escalate since the latest updates from Taiwan's conflict. Giving the date on which this should be happening
China and India agreed to disengage along their border on September 9. This reduces the likelihood of military on military conflict.

The most volatile region where this can happen is at the Indian borders, where fatal clashes happen frequently, the last was in 2020. Recently, India and China agreed on disengagement terms, effective September 12th, this month. On this basis, I would not expect any fatal confrontations to happen until 28th of November, especially with the ongoing Russian war.
Agreement was signed in September 12th.
My teammate convinced me to increase my probabilities.
I change my view after a classmate provides us with more information about China's past deadly confrontation and taking into consideration the timeline. this logic is as follows:

I would assign low odds to this. I am assuming China as the aggressor, as recent history suggests that its cross-border conflicts occur due to its territorial claims. The next CCP congress is on October 16th and the party will avoid anything that would prevent the event from going smoothly as Xi Jingping is reelected for another term. Tensions with India are somewhat stable, and as winter approaches in the Himalayas fighting would become harder for both sides. China is unlikely to invade Taiwan in the immediate term as that will invite conflict with the US, and in the case of other countries, tensions have been limited to light conflict and sabre-rattling.

In reviewing historical data, I don't foresee China engaging in lethal confrontation before November 28, 2022; however, I marked the probability as 5% given ongoing geopolitical tension between China and other international actors, including those listed in the description of this question.
It will be probably very unlikely due to the current global situation unless China takes a strong shift in its international affairs strategy.

Given it a fairly low probability (6%) based on first looking at the number of lethal confrontations China has had with any countries (<5%). Increased it slightly given on-going tensions with U.S. and other countries and also factoring in that the timeline is only till 28th November.

Lethal conflict, particularly in border zones with India, have occurred throughout the past few decades. Xi Jin Ping likely to become leader again at the upcoming PRC leadership conference and to start off his third term, he may attempt to show force for the domestic stage - particularly to distract from the ongoing domestic consequences of COVID-19.
- A)There was no former confrontations + huge implication if there is confrontation ;

China's most recent military in such a context was with India in July 2020. As recently as this month, the two countries have announced a mutual withdrawal of troops from the region. This make me believe that a chance or lethal engagement again is low given the time frame.

Given the current global political climate with Russia, it's unlikely that China will initiate conflict with another country within the next two months. Although China is becoming more aggressive and tensions with the US are high, it is unlikely that either of the two countries will take action to rock the boat in the near future. This is further corroborated with historical data as the the number of lethal conflicts involving China have been fairly low in the past decade, with the last being a cross-border skirmish with India in 2020.

Historically, China hasn’t had a strong record of lethal confrontation with other countries (before 2021, the last clash with India was 45 years before, for example). Although China is getting more confrontational, I think that the global focus on the war in Ukraine and its global economic consequences will stop China (and other countries) to start another diplomatic crisis in the region.

Given the focus of the world on the Ukrainian crisis, China might feel prone to engage on more assertive diplomatic activities. However, a lethal military confrontation should not be a feasible scenario. In particular, the Chinese Communist Party will hold its next Congress in October 2022, where Xi Jinping is expected to emerge once again as the uncontested leader. Engaging on a diplomatic crisis with another country may not be the most auspicious.
While China has become more confrontational, I think after Russia's aggression against Ukraine will deter China from taking any military action in the near future.

China had a relatively rare lethal confrontation with other countries. That, combined with the fact that Russia's war already gave pressure to their economy, would make it even less likely that China would decide to engage in such confrontation.

Given the focus on Russia and Ukraine, I think there could be more restraint from the PRC, even though Xi Jinping has met with Putin in solidarity of their respective claims to nearby territory. However, one fatality is a very low number and possible even in the event of an accident, which needs to be accounted for. I have also accounted for the fact that the last standoff between China and India with deaths was in 2020, killing 20 soldiers. Then, later in 2020, 4 soldiers died in a border clash. Another factor is that the US is involved to maintain peace and its goal is to do so. There is a desire to maintain peace and stability in the region. Given this, I put the probability at 13%, low but acknowledging that there could be a chance given that only one fatality is needed for this outcome to be positive.
Whilst tensions are high at the moment, no one wants a military confrontation in the winter, they'll wait it out and start chucking rocks in 2023.

With Putin's remarks today and China-Russia conversations recently, until see PRC movement in the field (am I missing anything anyone?) no major change yet. If anything happens there will be intense scrutiny and perhaps misunderstanding of intent, so maybe PRC takes more caution to not have a lethal confrontation right now. https://www.uscc.gov/research/chinas-position-russias-invasion-ukraine

The world environment is in turmoil—the tensions between China and Taiwan, the USA, and other countries. Two factors have further strained these relations: Pelosi's visit to Taiwan and the conflict between Russia and Ukraine, where China has never condemned Russian aggression. However, I consider the Chinese use of its national military force unlikely for November 28, 2022. Such a decision by China would force the USA and its allies to take delicate measures for the world, perhaps leading us to a third world war. That is why I think that in the case of China, making this decision is much more costly than that of Russia with Ukraine - which is not a member of NATO.

In the past 10 years, there have been several confrontations between China and its neighbours. However, only a few of those have been lethal. In the current international scenario, China has just seen Russia falter to the point of failure with its attack on Ukraine. USA issued a public statement stating that it would defend Taiwan in case of attack. Finally, Xi is set to be leader for life in mid-Oct, which is likely to keep him busy/engaged. For all these reasons, I believe the chances are less.

Relations between Taiwan and China have been deteriorating, and China has been sending military aircraft to Taiwan's air space for the last months. So it doesn't seem unlikely to me considering the definition of "lethal confrontation" (at least one fatality).

The timeframe under projection here is very short, particularly through the lens of time needed for a conflict to escalate significantly. We felt that the likeliest outcome for this to happen would probably be India/China due to shared border, but we still saw that as being <=10% likely to happen by November 28th (at a significant level). On the other hand, the bar being 1 fatality is actually relatively low relative to all-out conflict, so I adjusted up to 15%.

The last lethal confrontation between China and another country was with India in 2020. Although China currently has high tensions with many countries, the timeline is only of one month which lowers the probability that there will be a lethal confrontation before November 28.
Bumping back up considering that the question addresses lethal confrontation, not necessary war. China and India had some skirmishes where at least 1 person died in 2020
I adjusted based on the shorter timeframe.
As the war in Ukraine escalates, Chinese military/militia/law enforcement may be emboldened to act aggressively toward neighboring countries.
After seeing others, I anchored too high. Adjusting to something more reasonable and to the fact that it's only about two months.

Highly doubt it; a war of China with the countries that have the most tensions (to include the US) can be catastrophic and all involved know this (ie. all have nukes). Kinetic warfare is left for incompetents such as Putin and his joke of an Army. However, China has been showing her teeth to Taiwan and everything is possible.
Based on the number of fronts and the number of people in each front, and given the definition of a lethal confrontation, I believe this to be very possible.
Not sure, update tomorrow.

Based on a review of current news articles on China's relations with other countries, I don't see evidence to suggest lethal confrontation is imminent. While news media outlets are emphasizing that President Biden has stated that the United States would respond militarily to a Chinese invasion of Taiwan I don't think this increases the likelihood of lethal confrontation between the national military forces, militia, and/or law enforcement personnel the People's Republic of China (PRC) and those of any other country.

The previous base rate of lethal concentrations involving China and another country over the last 40 years was pegged at roughly 40% I am updating downward due to the time remaining for this question (~2 months) and the no significantly unprecedented news of late

As we learned from our guest lecturer, 8/20 confrontations by the PRC have resulted in death ("lethal"). However, Xi has been far more outspoken (and many of the confrontations that lead to death have occurred on this watch (if I'm remembering, it's 2/3 or something to that effect)). That sounds right to me: I'd anchor at 66%.
Still gross estimate to be soon updated.

I have found that the PRC has engaged in 12 lethal engagements over the past 73 years, suggesting a 16.34% chance of a lethal engagement in any given year. Given that there are 69 days until November 28th 2022, I will pro-rate this probability by dividing .1634 by 365 and multiplying it by 69, giving me 3 percent as a base rate. But i will adjust upwards to 5 percent, given increasing tensions across the region and a more pronounced posture of great power competition adopted by both China and the United States in recent years.
There hasn't been one yet. Additionally, President Biden recently reaffirmed his commitment to defending Taiwan which decreases the likelihood that China attacks it.

The anchor probability here seems to be very low (<5%) given that China has had few confrontations with any other country in the last 15-20 years. Adjusted it to be a bit higher for two reasons: 1) growing tensions between China and other countries over the last few years; 2) Xi Jingping might have to play to the local constitutency given economic constraints. Also haven't overadjusted it given the time frame scope.

I updated my forecast to 3% after discussions with my peers. Given the very small time frame, as well as the fact that in early September India and China pulled their troops back from the disputed border area, I decreased my forecast.
Updated it - time frame is quite narrow so i lowered to chances

We are talking about at least one fatality here. So, even though the chances of a lethal confrontation that might escalate to a war-type situation seem low (not nil), given how frequent Indo-China clashes at the borders are, the chances of a lethal confrontation resulting in at least one fatality seem reasonably high - also due to the animosity that China has with not one but multiple neighbors (India, Taiwan, Japan)!

I'd be very surprised if this occurs, since such confrontations are extremely rare to begin with and China seems to be urging moderation with Russia and the international community at the present moment. That said, with tensions still elevated over Taiwan, it's not something that can be completely discounted.

There has been only one lethal confrontation involving China in the past 20 years so despite the current International tensions over Taiwan, it is very unlikely that any lethal confrontation will occur in such a short amount of time

Although there has been significant tension after the visit of the Speaker of the US House of Representatives to Taiwan in early August, such tension does not seem to have escalated over the past weeks. The United States are very unlikely to engage in another similar act any time soon (seen as a provocation by China). China undertook military exercises as a response to the visit, to send a signal of their inconformity. Given those tensions, the parties will be very cautious and a confrontation is very unlikely in the near future. This is even more the case given the situation in Ukraine (I believe that far from encouraging China to be more assertive in Taiwan, the geopolitical tensions created by Russia's aggression of Ukraine will lead Chine to be cautious in a period of high global instability).
The last documented lethal confrontation between PRC forces and another country was on June 15, 2020 between China and India (Reuters). These events are rare though not unprecedented.
Adding a couple points on the back of the confirmed party congress date, this would almost be a 0% for prior to that date - Oct 16.
looking at Chinese interests at this time of the year -

November is roughly 1.5 months away. Chinese leadership recently attended the Shanghai Cooperation Organization summit, where President Xi expressed concern about Russia's military activity. This suggests that Xi may be conflict-averse at the moment. China also holds its five-year congress beginning on October 16, during which time Xi is expected to cement his place as the nation's most powerful leader. Following the conference his leadership and the PRC may be more bullish than before, but I believe that global uncertainty caused by Russia would tend to put China on a cooler footing.
Discussion with colleagues lead in direction that accidental mishaps during standoffs and training exercises will not count. Timeframe is getting narrower.
This would likely lead to other nations involvement.
Conflict with Taiwan is possible but unlikley

The last time Chinese forces engaged in lethal contact was 2020 with Indian forces. Both nations recently drew back from the border decreasing tensions. Other historical conflicts in the south china sea have not turned lethal. There is a very small chance of this occurring before November 2022.

The PRC is involved in at least two ongoing conflicts in Mali and across the China-India border. This indicates that that the probability of lethal confrontation is possible, especially along the China-India border. But there are many factors keeping my forecast low. First, President Xi Jing Ping and Prime Minister Narendra Modi met last week and ahead of that meeting, soldiers agreed to disengage from the region. It was the first time the two met since the COVID-19 outbreak. Secondly, Ukrainian forces had several recent victories; in this unequal conflict, greater military power and resources do not guarantee quick victory. Lastly and more directly, President Biden publicly said yesterday (9/18) that the US would defend Taiwan if the PRC were to invade. Although, the question does not specify a country, strong statements such as this, keeps my probability low.
Recently China maintained talks with India to solve the issue

China is actively engaged in establishing itself as a regional power in the Indo-Pacific and has large military, militia, and law enforcement organizations. While the Xi regime remains disciplined, there's still the possibility of an event occurring.

I think it is more likely that PRC and India has lethal confrontations given its recent historical border disputes where fatalities have occurred. Between China and Taiwan-Japan there hasn't been as much confrontation. China-Taiwan has had a lot of flights into their ADIZ but the deaths have been because of maintenance issues.
I don't think so

I initially put the probability at 1%, because while extremely unlikely there is always a chance, but I believe the probability is realistically closer to 0% than 1%, so rounding to the nearest percentage point would be 0%.

In the 2000s, China has not had a lethal confrontation with any country directly except India. Recently India and China have too started to disengage. It is unlikely anything will happen before mid-October when Xi is likely to get reelected. I will update my forecast after his election and continue monitoring. However, given the low likelihood of China engaging in any conflict directly with any country's forces and over Taiwan meaning war with the US (and possibly even Japan), and seeing how Ukraine has gone for Russia, this is the probability I would assign to China engaging in a lethal conflict with any country directly before 28 November 2022.

This question's broad definition leaves a really large possibility of it being true. PLA and PLA-N have regular and special forces located within multiple contested regions in Africa, South America, Southern Pakistan, the Gulf of Aden, the Indian Border, Tajikistan, and multiple other countries. If only one non-Chinese citizen and any one of these Chinese forces in any area have a violent conflict, the criteria would be met.

There have only been a small number of lethal confrontations that have occurred between the People's Republic of China and another country in the last decade. If a confrontation did occur, there is a low chance that it would be of a lethal nature. Given the India-China border dispute and the skirmishes in the past two years, there is a chance of confrontation there, but also uncertainty around whether there would be casualties. Since the time scope of this question is relatively narrow, I assigned a low probability of 10% to this event.

The outside view base rate of conflicts with at least one casualty is very low. If at all, the highest probability is likely India. Over such a short time period, conflict is unlikely, and if it does occur, casualties are unlikely. While tensions are never “low,” no recent headlines or coverage leads me to believe that the next two months are expected to be any higher than usual. Regarding Taiwan, I would expect any conflict would be preceded by some news coverage or public intelligence – I have not read anything persuasive yet. Press coverage always indicates some risk, but nothing indicating violent conflict with lethal potential. Surprises and accidents can certainly happen, but do not move me above the 1% threshold...yet. Should anything change, I will update.

There are at least 2 questions: is there a confrontation between now and 11/28? Does a confrontation have at least one person die. If someone in a confrontation slips/trips/falls/drowns or has an accidental death but wouldn't be there if there was no confrontation does that count? Don't peacetime exercises (which are underway right - PRC conducting as demonstrations to Taiwan) sadly have lethal outcomes for a few participants. I am unsure of the definitions of "confrontation" and "result in" wrt to the wording of this question. Are quarantines or blockades "confrontations?" I'm going to give my probability based on a possible misunderstanding on my part that I'm giving a forecast of an aggressive altercation and accidental deaths during exercises don't count.
one death,,,,

No. I think it's going to take them a year or two. But I'm certain they're going to take Taiwan in the next few years. Our government is preparing for this eventuality by moving chip production back home. We're cutting our losses. I understand that China is having issues with India, Japan, Taiwan, and the U.S., but it wouldn't make sense coming from China's perspective. China and Russia are friends, and I do believe China knows that things can go far worse than planned like the invasion of Ukraine. The United States has told China that there may be a chance of direct intervention if they invade Taiwan. If there was direct conflict, a large portion of Taiwan is covered in mountains, and China probably doesn't have a lot of experience fighting in the mountains, therefore Taiwan would have the advantage. Also, it would take YEARS if they were to be victorious and a lot of money to supply China's military. There is 0 percent chance China goes to war with Japan or India. Japan is part of NATO, and China would take whatever measures not to anger the NATO alliance. China and India have disputes all the time, including some brutal disputes in the past few years, but they never actually invaded one another. November 28 of 2022 is way too soon for China to engage in direct conflict with another country ,but my probability would be way higher if the question was in the next 40 years.

Adjusted average between three different forecasts of mine. One was a subjective one, one was taking the crowd consensus, and one was me thinking in broader terms and then dividing the probability over the time portion of the period this question is open for. Hint: my subjective one was the average of the 3. The adjustment down was to factor in the decline of the crowd consensus.

Though China is assuming more aggressive posturing near Taiwan, India and in the South China Sea, China is also aware of the heightened political tension across the world. Following the Russian invasion of Ukraine and the international backlash for it, China would be keenly aware that hostile lethal action will significantly harm present or future measures. The likeliness is further decreased given China's reorganization and reevaluation of its own armed forces after the Russian invasion's failures. For the past decade, China has been undergoing a military rearmament and doctrinal evolution which may have come under further examination in the recent months.
